comments.commentBody: It is unconscionable that the head of the US Dept. of Justice or Attorney General would dissemble under oath during his confirmation hearings before Congress.  Session's cutesy pixie smile and pleas of forgetfulness remind me of what a stereotypical Southern belle would act like if pulled over by a traffic cop.  She would inevitably smile, feign ignorance of the law or play up her ditsy women in distress playing card before the traffic cop, who in most cases would feel sorry for her pathetic case and let her on her way out of sympathy for her damsel in distress persona.  Similarly, Sessions, who is in the top cop position, claims that when he lied about not having any contacts with Russians during the Trump campaign, that he was forgetful.  Would this testimony fly if the defendant was an Al Qaeda sympathizer who claimed to have forgotten that he had contact with jihadis during a time that the FBI was investigating anyone who was involved with jihadi recruitment in the US?  Also, the FBI as an institution was tarnished when Director Comey gave a suspicious press conference just weeks before the election regarding Hillary Clinton's e-mails even though we now know there was no there there and her account was never hacked unlike VP Mike Pence's AOL private e-mail account.  Comey's role in colluding with the Trump campaign to undermine Clinton's campaign for the Presidency should be investigated along with bllionaire criminal Felix Sater, Dmitry Rybolovlev & the Bank of Cypress.
Thank you for helping to give us Sessions and the whole Trump team. Brilliant foresight in your constant take-down of Clinton during the campaign.

Bank of Cypress and the oligarchs, Comney and Trump's taxes need serious and aggressive investigation. The NYT and WAPO and a EU paper would do well to team up on pursuing these angles to elevate U.S. understanding of how bad "undue influence" is in this questionable presidency.  Perhaps then the GOP would have to protect the country, not their corporate funders and nonsensical Ayn Rand ideologues.
Add in the criminal bombing of Aleppo and other Syrian strikes the Russians conducted.
Especially since they did a better job of vetting the top U.S. candidates for Trump's administration than the Republican Senate.

Trump may not undo world order, but he is, if we let him, going to alter the nature of our political system. He has provided a joke of a health report. He has hdden his real financial situation. He has not divested himself of the sources of conflict of interest. He has continuously lied and made up non existent events. He has appointed persons to critical positions who are in opposition to the tasks they are called to perform. He has disparaged friends and giving comfort to enemies. He has threatened or bribed CEO's. He has given free rein to people to pollute, to hinder voting, to speculate on other people's savings. He has melded the interests of the country with his personal affairs. He has undermined several critical agencies of government. He has endangered two pillars of our society: free press and free judiciary.
And all this in spite of having the majority of the American people voting against him.

This simply means one thing: The US's governing system is proven to be obsolete and utterly dangerous. Many old rules and regulations, conceived centuries ago, are proving to be an  inadequate framework  to manage - evolvingly-  this new modern society of ours. Fix it and replace it or rot.
He turned the process into a reality TV show. And the Republican party let him trash it!
They might believe in active CYA, as the Russians also hacked the official (and unofficial) RNC servers. What misdeeds might be documented there?

Apart from the mistake on the lake, is there likely to be any smoking gun on the Russian connections? The hanky panky with the Russia pretty much all happened before Trump took office. There was no abuse of power before there was executive power to abuse. This does not seem like Watergate, when by the way the Congress was solidly in the hands of the Democrats.

Democrats should insist on Trump releasing his tax returns and divesting from his business empire conflicts of interest, and stop giving him free publicity by trying to play PC gotcha with every daily foot-in-mouth remark that comes out of this incompetent administration.

There's plenty of traitorous activity before the swearing-in ceremony. If Trump surrogates had anything to do with the Russian hacking, they committed crimes. These crimes continue now. The astonishing thing is that these things are done almost completely openly and then are boldly, dishonestly denied. The spineless and corrupt Republicans in Congress stand around wringing their hands and saying, "oh my" or simply denying there is a problem. Our politics have become like the Mad Hatter's tea party.

Every article and comment I have read lately begins with the supposition if Trump surrogates did this or that. Or, unnamed sources, or calling for impeachment with no evidence. The libs are connecting the dots of these meetings while having already decided Trump is guilty for colluding with the Russians. Until there is actual proof provided by any of the committees investigating the election or from the FBI,most people will not support any of the conspiracy theories written by the Times or their liberal readers. Sorry, that's how are system works and that is the law of the land.

"The libs are connecting the dots of these meetings while having already decided Trump is guilty for colluding with the Russians."

Might that have something to do with the president, while campaigning, openly inviting the Russians to hack his opponent's email.

Weren't tough dots to connect, Brian.

Sure, Richard, only help the worthy poor, which will guarantee that you never suffer the high cost of being "conned" - embarrassment. Nowhere does the Pope suggest "everlasting damnation" for being fearful, judgmental or miserly in the moment.
Why open with "always good advice" only to reject it?

Who? Follow the money: Paul Manafort, Carter Page, Roger Stone, Michael Flynn, Jefferson Sessions, TIllerson, Wilbur Ross all have or had Russian connections. U.S. intelligence agencies “intercepted communications and financial transactions” between Russian officials and Trump allies; specifically Roger Stone, Paul Manafort, and Carter Page. Worth a look:
http://mediamatters.org/blog/2017/01/19/new-york-times-trump-ally-roger-...

Amazing: a Pope suggesting that people, believers especially, behave in Christlike ways with fellow men. What I'm certain he knows from his long experience is that acknowledging the other as worthy of your attention enhances giver and receiver. It's Martin Buber's I-Thou, not I-it.

At this point it may take foreign governments--our principled European allies to summon documents that show Trump's network of transactions, money transfers, offshore accounts, laundering operations (for the Russians, etc.) and loans.

I have no problems at all with Manhattan taxis. I go back and forth to probably the most remote part of Brooklyn -- near the Fairway Market at the end of Van Brunt Street, and have never had a problem getting a cab driver to take me there. To be honest, I'm having a little trouble believing your claims, because all you'd need to do is report the driver if they refuse to take you anywhere. In fact, since a trip to Brooklyn is a big fare, I've found that drivers are more than willing to go there.

I am sure you are referring to the previous crowds - the armed tea partiers that were ginned up and funded by the Koch Brothers.

All you have to do is look at all the hand made signs.. people put thought and energy into what they wanted to express, as opposed to showing up and carrying what was mass produced and handed to them.

Walker is an old fashioned hard line Union buster.
It's the Unions that built the middle class of our country.
It's the breaking of the Unions, with the protection for workers, that has done a lot of damage to the middle class.

That's what happened when you demonize teachers...

Walker demonized teachers!!! As if their salaries with earned benefits could bring down the state. Walker is an enemy of quality education.

"Instead, they want all government to stay out of their lives"

...and right into the lives of 'their' women... as our health concerns become their battering ram..how we would love to keep Republican government out of our lives

The timing of the White House's "admission" that the son-in-law Kushner was involved was a bit curious, yes? Surely he wasn't keeping this from Ivanka and his father-in-law.  Was the WH forced to make its statement -- after someone in Congress "leaked" that it would come out in the press?

America may face a grave threat from Russia, a resurgent enemy power whose autocratic leader is its former chief spy. That aggressive country used cyberattacks to deliver victory to our new President, who has shown much interest in helping Russia in return.

Surrogates of President Trump met repeatedly with Russians during the campaign, and one of those surrogates is our chief law enforcement officer, Jeff Sessions. He gratuitously lied under oath to hide his meetings. Now, under pressure, Attorney General Sessions has recused himself from any investigation.

Someone needs to tell us why we should care that Sessions looks like one of Santa’s aging elves and that many of his former Senate colleagues like him.

We should care, however, that behind that sweet smile and that aw-shucks, self-effacing country manner is a brain filled with a rat’s nest of vile thoughts about publicly intimidating people of color and privately incarcerating them.

Common sense tells us that a man who makes light of the civil rights of average American citizens, is a man for whom cutting a cozy deal with a Russian dictator is never off the table.

To Jeff Sessions, Cleveland may seem like a strange, northern city with an uncomfortably diverse population, some of whom have accented speech. It does not, however, resemble Zurich, where espionage is an industry and meeting with spies is commonplace.

At this point, because even tax returns don't reveal everything....it should be noted that Trump owes hundred of millions of dollars to Deutsche Bank, the same Deutsche Bank caught laundering $10 billion of Putin Mafia money. This should be supoaned by international bodies.
Add in the rest of th feckless Republicans.

Sessions lied while under oath to our Congress so he's committed a felony. (He probably lied to the FBI as well - yet another felony) He should be promptly arrested and stand in the dock. Once there, we should offer him a plea bargain if he tells the truth about Trump, the Trump campaign, and the Russian involvement in the election.

The first question I would ask would be: How did the Russians use their video evidence of Trump in Moscow? It would be truly foolish to think that the Russians wouldn't have done so as it's way outside their normal modus operandi.

There are just too many Russian contacts with the Trump campaign for this to be a coincidence. Where there's smoke, there's fire. The only way through now is sunshine. We need to erase this blot from American history.
Sessions didn't lie, he "forgot."
Tax returns plus his offshore bank accounts should be subpoenad -- by those in Congress still  OR better yet European leaders who've similarly had their elections hacked.

When I served on a jury, we were instructed that isn we believed a witness had lied in any response, we should assume the witness may have lied in other responses.

Sessions lied under oath during his confirmation hearing. Case closed.

If I had lied under oath, I would expect to pay a penalty. He needs to go.
And soon, before he causes any more damage.
Any other employee would be fired.  If one of Sessions employees did something similar with him, he'd be gone instantly.  Rules don't apply to friends and appointees of Dear Leader.

Joseph: Respected business journals like Fortune Magazine showed how easy our voting systems are to hack. Check out Premier Election Systems page in Wikipedia also links for Hacking Democracy and Stealing America Vote by Vote. America relies on an insecure voting system--that along with gerrymandering-- can keep votes from being counted accurately as cast.
Their behavior raises the question: what did the Russians find when they hacked the RNC server(s)?

To an outsider it's puzzling. On one hand I find it difficult to believe that the Trump campaign would really have done something so crass and unsubtle as organising election interference via their senior people and the Russian ambassador without apparently any concern for how those meetings and phone calls might appear to other people.   On the other I find it impossible to believe that either Flynn or Sessions could genuinely have forgotten what they talked to the ambassador about.    It is also odd that no-one seems to think to ask the ambassador what he recalled the meetings as being about. People don't have to believe him, of course, but they could at least ask the question.

Louise, as you are from the UK it is understandable how you could find the apparent situation so difficult to believe. If you forget for a moment your respect for my country and consider its politicians as nothing more than people like those in any other country (even yours), you will no doubt remember that throughout history politicians have done despicable, traitorous, disreputable things for sinister reasons, even when they tell themselves they're doing the "right thing."

Our politicians are some of the worst in that they are elected by the people to serve the nation, and take an oath which they sometimes immediately violate. In our present predicament, the Republican Party has allowed a faction within it to steer the Party toward an abyss in which the Party is more important than the country it is supposed to serve. If our Congress was filled with a dictator's appointees they could almost be excused for serving the wrong master; ours utterly refuse to acknowledge their first priority and instead display complete contempt for those they serve.

The political history of the United States contains countless incidents of politicians, from presidents on down, who violated the People's trust. Many have been dealt with harshly, as they should be. This process will hopefully weed out the untrustworthy elements within our government and restore the faith the People should have in it.
Citizen, that is Right and let us remember that We also have a Tax-Free President!
@Louise. I believe a reporter did ask Kislyak about the contents of his conversations with Flynn and Sessions and he declined to disclose them.

Keep playing smallball on cspan while the real game proceeds out of sight.  What does a Federal AG do?  Nothing of import to this administration's intentions.  Any enforcement actions they desire can simply be carried out locally by Federal prosecutors and sympathetic DAs while not bothering with "preventions" the previous crowd wasted their time on.  Further, as noted in a separate column, the dismantling of big government does not require filling every vacancy, especially at the State Department, and indeed their emptiness serves again this administration's plans.  As to investigations, special prosecutors and the other hijinks, go for it.  Wait until current holdover employees, like those at State, are hauled in under oath to testify about the Clinton state department's contacts and meetings with foreigners and the subsequent "donations" to her family enterprise.  Oops!  Concerned with employment, careers and pensions, these loyalists will sing like canaries on steroids.  You reap what you sow, ersatz strategists.  The penetration of the deep state, and its exposure and expungement, continue unabated.
LOL, On no not the infamous "deep state".  Talk about "small ball".
Deep State? You really believe that swill they serve up at Breitbart?

Arduin, a Prince of a guy, and let us hold on to the Policy of Fear, State first, People next, and the Nation will be buying guns like lollipops. Donald Duck will be quacking that pollution is caused by trees; a nation of hypocritical preachers with the brains of pterodactyls and politicians who would sell their daughters for a vote, and let us not forget Mr. Reagan who once visited Mississippi where three civil rights workers were lynched. He declared that he stood for States' Rights, and every good ol'boy from Tallahassee to Kalamazoo got the message.

Now when it comes to sessions with Jeff Sessions, well now, he is quite sure, even confident although he cannot quite remember, that there has been no hanky pank playing on his part with Russia. If we could just give the new Attorney General a moment to breathe, let's see some phone logs maintained by his office and expect to hear that this is not the policy of his Office. No, Sir.
